nodes.text: Ergodicity economics (EE) is pseudoscience because it has produced few falsifiable implications and meets multiple indicators of pseudoscience
EE prescribes growth rate optimization: maximize long-run geometric average growth rate
Method: two-asset continuous-time portfolio model with risky asset price following geometric Brownian motion and constant rebalanced portfolio fraction theta
Result (EE prescription in the model): optimal portfolio theta_EE = (mu - r) / sigma^2 obtained by maximizing long-run average log growth
Result (EUT prescription in the model): expected utility maximization with CRRA utility yields optimal theta_EUT = (mu - r) / (gamma sigma^2)
Claim: EE and expected utility theory (EUT) make identical portfolio predictions in this model only when relative risk aversion gamma = 1 (log utility)

Claim: Because EE and EUT coincide only in special cases and EE has not provided broader testable prescriptions for more general economic problems, EE has produced few testable implications and is not currently falsifiable
Evidence: Peters has not developed widely applicable testable extensions (e.g., multi-period consumption-investment problems) over more than a decade

Claim: EE meets multiple Wikipedia indicators of pseudoscience: (i) vague or untestable claims, (ii) improper collection or misuse of evidence, (iii) limited openness to expert testing, (iv) absence of progress, (v) personalization, and (vi) misleading language

Evidence: Specific examples include grandiose assertions resolving decision theory without concrete testable applications, selective or out-of-context citations, most publications outside core economics venues, and reliance on older literature
Limitation: Author is not an EE specialist and restricts analysis mainly to Peters 2019 paper published in Nature Physics

Conclusion: Given the lack of presently falsifiable implications and the presence of multiple pseudoscience indicators, EE should be treated with skepticism and avoided until it produces concrete testable predictions reviewed by economic experts
